docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Querpyable

A Python implementation of LINQ

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
# Calculating the first 10000 primes
Queryable \
  .range(2, 1_000_000) \
  .where(lambda n: all(n % i != 0 for i in range(2, int(n ** 0.5) + 1))) \
  .take(10000)

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
pip install querpyable

In order to locally set up the project please follow the instructions below:

# Set up the GitHub repository
git clone https://github.com/billsioros/querpyable

# Create a virtual environment using poetry and install the required dependencies
poetry shell
poetry install

# Install pre-commit hooks
pre-commit install --install-hooks
pre-commit autoupdate

docs.title: Our Pledge
docs.text: In the interest of fostering an open and welcoming environment, we as contributors and maintainers pledge to make participation in our project and our community a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body size, disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity and expression, level of experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, or sexual identity and orientation.

docs.title: Our Standards
docs.text:
Examples of behavior that contributes to creating a positive environment include:

  • Using welcoming and inclusive language
  • Being respectful of differing viewpoints and experiences
  • Gracefully accepting constructive criticism
  • Focusing on what is best for the community
  • Showing empathy towards other community members

Examples of unacceptable behavior by participants include:

  • The use of sexualized language or imagery and unwelcome sexual attention or advances
  • Trolling, insulting/derogatory comments, and personal or political attacks
  • Public or private harassment
  • Publishing others' private information, such as a physical or electronic address, without explicit permission
  • Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a professional setting

docs.title: Our Responsibilities
docs.text:
Project maintainers are responsible for clarifying the standards of acceptable behavior and are expected to take appropriate and fair corrective action in response to any instances of unacceptable behavior.

Project maintainers have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, and other contributions that are not aligned to this Code of Conduct, or to ban temporarily or permanently any contributor for other behaviors that they deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, or harmful.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: This Code of Conduct applies within all project spaces, and it also applies when an individual is representing the project or its community in public spaces. Examples of representing a project or community include using an official project e-mail address, posting via an official social media account, or acting as an appointed representative at an online or offline event. Representation of a project may be further defined and clarified by project maintainers.

docs.title: Enforcement
docs.text:
Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior may be reported by contacting one of the project maintainers listed below. All complaints will be reviewed and investigated and will result in a response that is deemed necessary and appropriate to the circumstances. The project team is obligated to maintain confidentiality with regard to the reporter of an incident. Further details of specific enforcement policies may be posted separately.

Project maintainers who do not follow or enforce the Code of Conduct in good faith may face temporary or permanent repercussions as determined by other members of the project's leadership.

docs.title: Project Maintainers
docs.text: • Vasilis Sioros <billsioros97@gmail.com>

For answers to common questions about this code of conduct, see https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
Hello and thank you for considering contributing to querpyable!

Reading and following these guidelines will help us make the contribution process easy and effective for everyone involved.

docs.title: Code of Conduct
docs.text: By participating and contributing to this project, you agree to uphold our Code of Conduct.

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text: In case all you need is an answer to a question, please refrain from opening an issue and instead visit the project's discussion page.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
Contributions are made to this repository via Issues and Pull Requests (PRs). A few general guidelines that cover both:

  • Search for existing Issues and PRs before creating your own.
  • We work hard to make sure issues are handled in a timely manner but, depending on the impact, it could take a while to investigate the root cause. A friendly ping in the comment thread to the submitter or a contributor can help draw attention if your issue is blocking.

docs.title: Issues
docs.text:
Issues should be used to report problems with the library or request a new feature or documentation change. When you create a new Issue, a template will be loaded that will guide you through collecting and providing the required information.

If you find an Issue that addresses the problem you're having, please add your own reproduction information to the existing issue rather than creating a new one. Adding a reaction can also help in indicating to our maintainers that a particular problem is affecting more than just the reporter.

docs.title: Pull Requests
docs.text:
PRs can be a quick way to get your fix or improvement slated for the next release. In general, PRs should:

  • Only fix/add the functionality in question OR address wide-spread whitespace/style issues, not both.
  • Address a single concern in the least number of changed lines as possible.
  • Be accompanied by a complete Pull Request template (loaded automatically when a PR is created).
  • Add unit or integration tests for added or changed functionality.
  • Any code related changes should be accompanied by corresponding changes to the project's documentation.
  • If your pull request introduces a new feature, the corresponding README section must be updated to reflect this.
  • Write clear, concise commit message(s) using the Conventional Commits format. Why?
  • This project only accepts pull requests related to open issues. In case there is no relevant open issue, feel free to create one.

For changes that address core functionality or would require breaking changes (e.g. a major release), it's best to open an Issue to discuss your proposal first. This is not required but can save time creating and reviewing changes.

In general, we follow the "fork-and-pull" Git workflow

  1. Fork the repository to your own Github account
  2. Clone the project to your machine
  3. Create a branch locally with a succinct but descriptive name
  4. Commit changes to the branch
  5. Push changes to your fork
  6. Open a PR in our repository and follow the PR template so that we can efficiently review the changes

docs.title: Setting up a local development environment
docs.text: The following sections assume that you have already locally cloned the repository.

docs.title: Installing Poetry
docs.text: The querpyable project utilizes the Poetry Python package manager. Having installed Poetry in the global namespace you may now run poetry shell to create a brand new virtual environment and poetry install, in order to install the project's dependencies (development dependencies as well).

docs.title: Installing pre-commit hooks
docs.text: The project utilizes the pre-commit framework. Having created a virtual environment and installed the required dependencies, you may run pre-commit install --install-hooks to install the git hook scripts.

docs.title: Testing via pytest
docs.text:
We are using pytest to automate testing on multiple environments.

The test suite can be run using poetry run poe test.

docs.title: (Optional) Installing pyenv
docs.text:
pyenv is used, in the context of the querpyable project, in order to determine the project's compatibility with various versions of Python. Installing pyenv is not strictly required, but it is recommended.

Having installed pyenv in the global namespace, you may now run the following snippet, in order to install Python 3.7, 3.8 and 3.9, which, at the time of writing this document, are the only Python versions, supported by querpyable.

pyenv install 3.7.10 3.8.9 3.9.4
pyenv local 3.7.10 3.8.9 3.9.4

Feel free to read more about using pyenv, in the context of poetry, here.

docs.title: Performing development operations via poethepoet
docs.text:
We are using poethepoet, to perform various development oriented tasks.

Formatting, type-checking, running the test suite, as well as a few other operations, can be performed by running poe <task>. Please run poe --help (or poetry run poe --help), to list all available operations.

docs.title: Documenting your changes
docs.text:
querpyable utilizes MkDocs to build and deploy its documentation to GitHub Pages. The documentation is auto-generated from the python docstrings throughout the source code. As a result, any code related change should be accompanied by a corresponding change to the method's / class's docstring.

Having made your changes, please run poe docs and make sure that no error is being raised on build time. Afterwards, open http://localhost:8000/ in your browser of choice and make sure that the documentation renders correctly.

docs.title: Writing your commit message
docs.text: The project's version number and Changelog, depend on a consistent commit history. As a result, your commit message's format is extremely important. Before opening a pull request, please make sure that your commits strictly follow the Conventional Commits format].

docs.title: Creating a pull request
docs.text: Make sure you review our Pull Request Guidelines, before initiating a PR.

docs.title: Binary
docs.text:
Bases: ABC

Base class for binary operations.

docs.title: __call__(source1, source2) abstractmethod
docs.text:
Applies an operation to two source sequences.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default source1 Iterable[T]

The first source sequence.

required source2 Iterable[U]

The second source sequence.

required

Returns:

Type Description Iterable[T]

Iterable[T]: The resulting sequence after applying the operation.

Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
@abstractmethod
def __call__(
    self,
    source1: Iterable[T],
    source2: Iterable[U],
) -> Iterable[T]:
"""Applies an operation to two source sequences.

    Args:
        source1 (Iterable[T]): The first source sequence.
        source2 (Iterable[U]): The second source sequence.

    Returns:
        Iterable[T]: The resulting sequence after applying the operation.
    """

docs.title: Distinct
docs.text: Bases: Unary

docs.title: __call__(source)
docs.text:
Filters out duplicate elements from the source sequence.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default source Iterable[T]

The source sequence.

required

Yields:

Name Type Description T Iterable[T]

The unique elements from the source sequence.

Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __call__(self, source: Iterable[T]) -> Iterable[T]:
"""Filters out duplicate elements from the source sequence.

    Args:
        source (Iterable[T]): The source sequence.

    Yields:
        T: The unique elements from the source sequence.
    """
    seen = set()
    for item in source:
        if item not in seen:
            seen.add(item)
            yield item

docs.title: Join(inner, outer_key_selector, inner_key_selector, result_selector)
docs.text:
Bases: Binary

Binary operation that joins two iterables based on key selectors and applies a result selector.

Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __init__(
    self,
    inner: Iterable[U],
    outer_key_selector: Callable[[T], K],
    inner_key_selector: Callable[[U], K],
    result_selector: Callable[[T, U], V],
) -> None:
    self.inner = inner
    self.outer_key_selector = outer_key_selector
    self.inner_key_selector = inner_key_selector
    self.result_selector = result_selector

docs.title: OrderBy(key_selector)
docs.text:
Bases: Unary

A class representing an order by operation on a sequence of elements.

Initialize a new instance of the OrderBy class.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default key_selector Callable[[T], U]

A callable object that takes an element from the source sequence and returns a key used for sorting.

required

Returns:

Type Description None

None

Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __init__(self, key_selector: Callable[[T], U]) -> None:
"""Initialize a new instance of the OrderBy class.

    Args:
        key_selector (Callable[[T], U]): A callable object that takes an element
            from the source sequence and returns a key used for sorting.

    Returns:
        None
    """
    self.key_selector = key_selector

docs.title: __call__(source)
docs.text:
Apply the order by operation on the source sequence.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default source Iterable[T]

The source sequence to order.

required

Yields:

Type Description Iterable[T]

Iterable[T]: The ordered sequence of elements.

Returns:

Type Description Iterable[T]

None

Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __call__(self, source: Iterable[T]) -> Iterable[T]:
"""Apply the order by operation on the source sequence.

    Args:
        source (Iterable[T]): The source sequence to order.

    Yields:
        Iterable[T]: The ordered sequence of elements.

    Returns:
        None
    """
    yield from (item for item in sorted(source, key=self.key_selector))

docs.title: OrderByDescending(key_selector)
docs.text:
Bases: Unary

Represents an operation that orders the elements in a sequence in descending order based on a key selector function.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default key_selector Callable[[T], U]

A callable that takes an element of type T and returns a key of type U.

required

Returns:

Type Description

An iterable containing the elements in descending order based on the key selector.

Initialize the OrderByDescending operation.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default key_selector Callable[[T], U]

A function that maps elements to keys used for sorting.

required Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __init__(self, key_selector: Callable[[T], U]) -> None:
"""Initialize the OrderByDescending operation.

    Args:
        key_selector: A function that maps elements to keys used for sorting.
    """
    self.key_selector = key_selector

docs.title: __call__(source)
docs.text:
Orders the elements in the source iterable in descending order based on the key selector.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default source Iterable[T]

An iterable of elements to be sorted.

required

Returns:

Type Description Iterable[T]

An iterable containing the elements in descending order based on the key selector.

Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __call__(self, source: Iterable[T]) -> Iterable[T]:
"""Orders the elements in the source iterable in descending order based on the
    key selector.

    Args:
        source: An iterable of elements to be sorted.

    Returns:
        An iterable containing the elements in descending order based on the key selector.
    """
    yield from (item for item in sorted(source, key=self.key_selector, reverse=True))

docs.text:

Initializes a new instance of the Select class.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default selector Callable[[T], U]

A transform function to apply to each element.

required Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __init__(self, selector: Callable[[T], U]) -> None:
"""Initializes a new instance of the Select class.

    Args:
        selector (Callable[[T], U]): A transform function to apply to each element.
    """
    self.selector = selector

docs.title: __call__(source)
docs.text:
Projects each element of a sequence into a new form.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default source Iterable[T]

The source sequence.

required

Yields:

Type Description Iterable[U]

Iterable[U]: The resulting sequence after applying the transform function.

Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __call__(self, source: Iterable[T]) -> Iterable[U]:
"""Projects each element of a sequence into a new form.

    Args:
        source (Iterable[T]): The source sequence.

    Yields:
        Iterable[U]: The resulting sequence after applying the transform function.
    """
    yield from (self.selector(item) for item in source)

docs.title: SelectMany(selector)
docs.text:
Bases: Unary

Initializes a new instance of the SelectMany class.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default selector Callable[[T], Iterable[U]]

A function that projects each element of the source sequence to an iterable.

required Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __init__(self, selector: Callable[[T], Iterable[U]]) -> None:
"""Initializes a new instance of the SelectMany class.

    Args:
        selector (Callable[[T], Iterable[U]]): A function that projects each element of the source sequence to an iterable.
    """
    self.selector = selector

docs.title: __call__(source)
docs.text:
Projects each element of the source sequence to an iterable and flattens the resulting sequences into one sequence.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default selector Callable[[T], Iterable[U]]

A function that projects each element of the source sequence to an iterable.

required

Yields:

Name Type Description U Iterable[U]

The flattened sequence of projected elements.

Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __call__(self, source: Iterable[T]) -> Iterable[U]:
"""Projects each element of the source sequence to an iterable and flattens the
    resulting sequences into one sequence.

    Args:
        selector (Callable[[T], Iterable[U]]): A function that projects each element of the source sequence to an iterable.

    Yields:
        U: The flattened sequence of projected elements.
    """
    for item in source:
        yield from self.selector(item)

docs.title: Skip(count)
docs.text:
Bases: Unary

Initializes a new instance of the Skip class.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default count int

The number of elements to skip from the start of the source sequence.

required Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __init__(self, count: int) -> None:
"""Initializes a new instance of the Skip class.

    Args:
        count (int): The number of elements to skip from the start of the source sequence.
    """
    self.count = count

docs.title: __call__(source)
docs.text:
Skips the specified number of elements in the sequence.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default source Iterable[T]

The input sequence.

required

Returns:

Type Description Iterable[T]

An iterable representing the result of skipping the elements.

Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __call__(self, source: Iterable[T]) -> Iterable[T]:
"""Skips the specified number of elements in the sequence.

    Args:
        source: The input sequence.

    Returns:
        An iterable representing the result of skipping the elements.
    """
    for index, item in enumerate(source):
        if index >= self.count:
            yield item

docs.title: Take(count)
docs.text:
Bases: Unary

Initializes a new instance of the Take class.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default count int

The number of elements to take from the source sequence.

required Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __init__(self, count: int) -> None:
"""Initializes a new instance of the Take class.

    Args:
        count (int): The number of elements to take from the source sequence.
    """
    self.count = count

docs.title: __call__(source)
docs.text:
Returns a specified number of contiguous elements from the start of a sequence.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default source Iterable[T]

The source sequence.

required

Yields:

Type Description Iterable[T]

Iterable[T]: The resulting sequence with the specified number of elements.

Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __call__(self, source: Iterable[T]) -> Iterable[T]:
"""Returns a specified number of contiguous elements from the start of a
    sequence.

    Args:
        source (Iterable[T]): The source sequence.

    Yields:
        Iterable[T]: The resulting sequence with the specified number of elements.
    """
    yield from (item for _, item in zip(range(self.count), source))

docs.text:
Orders the elements in the source iterable with subsequent ordering based on the key selector.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default source Iterable[T]

An iterable of elements to be sorted.

required

Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __call__(self, source: Iterable[T]) -> Iterable[T]:
"""Orders the elements in the source iterable with subsequent ordering based on
    the key selector.

    Args:
        source: An iterable of elements to be sorted.

    Returns:
        An iterable containing the elements with subsequent ordering based on the key selector.
    """
    yield from (item for item in sorted(source, key=self.key_selector, reverse=False))

docs.title: Where(predicate)
docs.text:
Bases: Unary

Initializes a new instance of the Where class.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default predicate Callable[[T], bool]

A function to test each element for a condition.

required Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __init__(self, predicate: Callable[[T], bool]) -> None:
"""Initializes a new instance of the Where class.

    Args:
        predicate (Callable[[T], bool]): A function to test each element for a condition.
    """
    self.predicate = predicate

docs.title: __call__(source)
docs.text:
Filters a sequence of values based on a predicate.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default source Iterable[T]

The source sequence.

required

Yields:

Type Description Iterable[T]

Iterable[T]: The resulting sequence after filtering elements based on the predicate.

Source code in src/querpyable/querpyable.py 
def __call__(self, source: Iterable[T]) -> Iterable[T]:
"""Filters a sequence of values based on a predicate.

    Args:
        source (Iterable[T]): The source sequence.

    Yields:
        Iterable[T]: The resulting sequence after filtering elements based on the predicate.
    """
    yield from (item for item in source if self.predicate(item))
